The writer might well say, on general grounds, of the ruler whom he had in mind, that he would be suc cessful in his enterprises and overcome the greatest difficulties. Line 1 is strong, but its low position might seem to debar its sub ject from any great enterprise. Favoured as he is, however, according to the general idea of the hexagram, and specially responding to the proper correlate in 4, it is natural that he should make a movement, and great success will make his rashness be forgotten. With paragraph 2 compare paragraph 5 of the preceding hexa gram. Line 2 is weak, but in the centre, and is the correlate of 5 . Friends give its subject the valuable gifts mentioned; ‘that is,’ says Kwo Yung (Sung dynasty), ‘men benefit him; the oracles of the divination are in his favour,—spirits, that is, benefit him; and finally, when the king sacrifices to God, He accepts. Heaven confers benefit from above.’ Line 3 is weak, neither central, nor in its correct position. It would seem therefore that its subject should have no increase given to him. But it is the time for giving increase, and the idea of his receiving it by means of evil things is put into the line. That such things serve for reproof and correction is well known to Chinese moralists. But the paragraph goes on also to caution and admonish. In Kwai we have the hexagram of the third month, when the last remnant, cold and dark, of winter, represented by the sixth line, is about to disappear before the advance of the warm and bright days of the approaching summer. In the yin line at the top king Win saw the symbol of a small or bad man, a feudal prince or high minister, lending his power to maintain a corrupt government, or, it might be, a dynasty that was waxen old and ready to vanish away; and in the five undivided lines he saw the representatives of good order, or, it might be, the dynasty which was to supersede the other. This then is the subject of the hexa gram,—how bad men, statesmen corrupt and yet powerful, are to be put out of the way. core_meaning.normalized_summary: This is a decisive break. Corruption or harmful influence has to be called out publicly and removed — but with awareness of danger, not reckless force. You announce the truth openly, gather support, and act with firm justice. The aim is principled resolution, not personal rage or premature violence.

translations.text: 1. The first line, undivided, shows its subject in (the pride of) strength advancing with his toes. He goes forward, but will not succeed. There will be ground for blame.
初九：壯于前趾，往不勝為咎。

lines.normalized_meaning: Rushing ahead on raw force and ego — leading with your toes — fails. If you charge too fast just because you feel strong, you get blamed.

translations.text: 2. The second line, undivided, shows its subject full of apprehension and appealing (for sympathy and help). Late at night hostile measures may be (taken against him), but he need not be anxious about them.
九二：惕號，莫夜有戎，勿恤。

lines.normalized_meaning: You raise the alarm and call for support. Enemies may move under cover of night, but if you stay alert and sincere, you don’t actually need to panic.

九三：壯于頄，有凶。君子夬夬，獨行，遇雨，若濡，有慍，無咎。

lines.normalized_meaning: You act with fierce resolve and may have to stand alone, getting ‘soaked’ and resented for it. People might distrust you for challenging corruption — but in the end you’re not blamed.

lines.normalized_meaning: You’re exhausted, exposed, and hurting. If you would just let yourself be guided calmly (like a led sheep), regret could fade — but pride makes you resist that advice.

lines.normalized_meaning: Corruption has spread like weeds. You must root it out completely, but do it from a centered, rightful position — focused justice, not rage — and you stay blameless.
